25331734.review:
The Epic Battle Fantasy series (or EBF for short) is a fantastic series, with an interesting origin story. It began as a simple wave by wave RPG, without much reason as to why you fight. It featured many cameos from famous franchises. In this installment and on, this was where the series began to adopt its own identity, saving cameos for mere references (some more obvious than others). I am a huge fan of the series, and I'm excited to see it reach beyond its "flash" game status. It may look, sound and play like one, but Matt (aka KupoGames) Rozsak knows to stretch its limits to create a wonderful game.


The customization is wonderful in this game. There are three characters, two of them male and one female. This dictates what equipment they can use. All three have their own unique weapon, and those weapons including their clothes, can be forged to become better. You may find certain equipment just plain better than others, if they essentially give the same resistants. The characters' clothes appear in the pictures of the dialogue boxes, and while wandering on the overworld, and of course in battle. I love when games do this.

The music, by the amazing Phyrnna (the game explains this in one of the menus viewable from the main menu) is phenomenal. Easy to get stuck in your head.


This is where I shift to comparing this one to EBF4. Obviously, you may think that this one's better because it's free on Steam compared to that, right? Well, I suppose, but...
I'd argue the fourth game is much better. Menu management was slightly more difficult in this one compared to the fourth, even playing this one before. In EBF4, gone is most of the text walls, and statistics and elements are made into easy identifiable pictures. When seeing enemy weaknesses, instead of percentages (like in EBF4), it is just text in this game. I personally don't find it a problem since it typically wouldn't want to use a resisted element on an enemy, but for those who have a hard time remembering which enemies actually absorb or resist elements it can make it quite a hassle.

You can always scan enemies to see their weaknesses and resistances. However, in this game, you can only scan one enemy at a time, and only Lance, can do it. You can always flee from the fight and restart to get free scans, but this may be tedious. In the fourth game, the scan becomes a scanbot, and a Summon that anyone can use, as well as being able to scan every new enemy in battle. Obviously I can't be too hard on it, since this one did come out first.

The game's humor, you could say, comes partly from Internet memes. Obviously not everyone is going to care all that much for it, but the humor doesn't neccessarily stop there. I'm not going too much into detail because well... its a side thing. Humor isn't that important here. There are a few grammatical errors, but that's alright. It shouldn't ruin your fun of the game. Many of them are also probably intentional anyhow, for the "illiterate" NPCs. I'm sure I've made a few in this review anyhow.

At its core, this is an RPG series where the main idea is just having fun destroying foes with sheer numbers, and obliterating them as their waves come. It definitely takes its inspiration from other RPG series, but it's all in good fun, and it revels in its craziness.

TL;DR

If you just like having a fun time, and a fairly difficult albeit short game (hey we can't be that ambitious for a previously Flash game) this is the one for you. If you're deciding on this game or EBF4, I would say start with this one, even though I've mentioned the other one is better. This is free, and in case you linger for more than two hours on the sequel only to find its not your style, you should let this one dictate how much you enjoy the battles. Yes, the menus are a bit more difficult to manage in this one, but the battles are what count mostly. Base your opinion on that.

25325067.review:
Don't mind the hours; I've played this since 2010 in-browser

Long ago, in the days before I had Steam, I spent my time playing free games online, and I still remember a handful of true gems that I would gladly pay money to play today (meanwhile there are some expensive piles of garbage still being made to this day). Epic Battle Fantasy is one such gem.
It is said that, to be successful, you just have to be a little bit better than everyone else, and in every way, EBF3 delivered. It was visually and auditorily appealing, full to the brim with hilarious dialogue and vivacious characters; the kind you'd want to be friends with in real life (as opposed to boring, only-tells-you-what-to-do, tutorial-bots I'd seen in so many others).
I was thrown into an entire world, a series of games created by an excellent developer, and I have fallen in love with every aspect of it (and I eagerly await the release of EBF5).

But enough about my experience. You want to know why you should give this game the time of day.
I'll tell you why:
Because it will make you laugh incessantly and nostalgically.
Because you will meet new people and want to get to know them better.
Because you will feel the rush of hearing the sound of an enemy's skull crushing, or the elegant creak of a chest opening, revealing loot you've never heard of before.
Because you will find hilarious and mysterious surprises around every corner, and wonder what else lies in wait for you to discover.
Because you will learn everything you need to know to get the most out of EBF4, which takes all the great aspects of this game and guilds them in a polish of pure, unadulterated, fun.

Because this is a game series that you find only a few times a generation, and it'll be something for you to share with those to come.

This is a series created by someone who truly loves what they do, and it's alarming how infrequent that can be in the free-to-play genre. This game is not pay2win. This game is not swarming with ads. This game is not a shoddily-made, RPGMaker practice-project. It is a good game. It is a great game. It is a game you should download right now and I DARE you to prove me wrong.

*DISCLAIMER*
Extreme nostalgia may affect the perspective of title portrayed in review.
(but seriously, there's not much need for reviews on free games. Review it yourself lazy bones.)

Kupo has always made games that shine, and this is one of them. A lot of love and work has been put into EB3, as evidenced by the strong gameplay, engaging dialogue and genuinely entertaining difficulty. While EBF4 is a step-up in every way, EB3 is free and it'll tell you if you would like EB4 (Which isn't very expensive, either!)

The game is a decently deep turn-based RPG, focusing on the three party members; Matt, who likes swords, Natalie the mage and Lance the colonel. They each come with a variety of custom skills and abilties to unlock and level up, providing multiple different play-styles. There is also three slots of Gear for each character, for head, body and weapon. While the standard style would be Matt as a tank, Lance as DPS and Natalie as support, you can switch it around however you want. Matt can be a proficient Mage DPS, Lance can be support and Natalie can...Well, she can be a mage, but the choice to bonk things with her is there.

A lot of game is here, and a lot of fun. If the game wasn't free, I would be more objective about it, but even if I made this review a "What-If" scenario if the game cost, it would be a far, far different story. Experience one of Kupo's adventures, and then salivate for more! I've played his games since the first Epic Battle Fantasy, and they always please. He has a devblog located at http://kupogames.com/category/epic-battle-fantasy-5/ ,
so feel free to check out the progress on EBF5!

Keep it up, Matt! I love your games!

25309589.review:
Played this for free on Kongregate and loved every minute of it. The fact that I can play it here on Steam is a dream come true.

A quick run through of this game with Epic Battle Fantasy 4 in mind (which I proudly own), there is a big gap in quality and content. Not saying that this game is bad, but if you play EBF3 and EBF4 back-to-back you can see the dramatic improvements he made on his open-world anime style turn-based RPG series. 

While significantly limited in scope compared to EBF4, it still has all of these elements which make it a game that should not be skipped in favor of trying out the much more polished sequel:

[*]a great soundtrack
[*]interesting enemy designs (the slimes will forever remain adorable)
[*]funny dialogue and endearing protagonists
[*]collectible weapons and clothing with different elemental effects and buffs to be changed depending on enemy type
[*]skills to learn and to be upgraded along with your gear
[*]a nice time-wasting, recurring mini game great recurring mini-game
[*]Straightforward game mechanics
[*]Silly shout-outs, self references, and obvious nods to various anime/cartoon series
[*]Enemies that scale fairly well with your character; no blindsiding jumps in difficulty between areas
[*]Differently-themed areas to traverse, each with their own special kind of enemies
[*]Tons of secrets hidden throughout the game filled with items, crafting materials, and equips

Play this game, enjoy it, and then head over to EBF4 to have your mind blown at how far Kupo's skills have advanced in game design in the time between the two games. The fact that this is free when there are dozens of RPGMaker-based games on Steam that have much less content and charm and expect you to pay for them...why wouldn't you play this game?

25291556.review:
BE SURE TO NOMINATE THIS FOR "BEST USE OF A FARM ANIMAL" FOR WHAT IT DOES TO CHICKENS!

Nowadays when I grab myself a new RPG, I find that most of my time is spent leveling and boosting stats, typically only finding a real challenge if I crank it up to the hardest difficulty, or play a Nuzlocke when it's pokemon. Why is this? Most modern RPGs seem to test the player's patience and ability to continue level grinding and farming drops. This isn't necessarily a bad thing in games such as MMOs, but when I'm enjoying a story-driven single player game, I'd like to feel a little more immersed. 

Epic Battle Fantasy, on the other hand, takes the concept of grinding and throws it in the shredder. Most of the leveling you need is obtained just by playing through the story, so the only time you'll find yourself fighting extra enemies on the side is if you want to upgrade some skills with AP, a point system used to unlock new skills and make them stronger. By the end of the game, the player will likely be at max level and have all skills maxed, so being underleveled at any given point isn't really a thing that could happen.

These points aren't even the greatest part of why I recommend the series, though. As I said, in most RPGs you can just grind for some time and then be absolutely golden for the remainder of the game. In Epic Battle Fantasy, however, no matter how overleveled you think you may be, you'll be on-edge and strategizing through every battle, even the normal encounters (Though ESPECIALLY with bosses, obviously). You need to think about what elements to use, and what elements to protect yourself from with equipment, which you can switch mid-battle in case the enemies vary in type. 

Without proper preparation, you could start a turn with full HP, and end the turn with a game over. However, this isn't necessarily a bad thing; in fact, I believe it to be an amazing feeling. Plus, if it's too much for you, you can always just hit up easy mode. There's 4 difficulty settings so it's pretty accessible for anybody. 

My overall point here is that the EBF games give a nostalgic RPG feel that most modern games can't deliver anymore because they all revolve around grinding for success now. Epic Battle Fantasy brings back the concept of ACTUALLY THINKING through your battles, and I absolutely love it for that.


...oh, and there's boob jiggles :)

25290081.review:
[h1]One of the best free RPGs has arrived on Steam.[/h1]

Let me start of by saying this. Dont mention my playtime. I have played this game back in the days on the internet. 

I hope I can give you an insight about this masterpiece, that is called EBF3. I will go through every possible aspect of this game and give it a final score.
But what exactly do you do in EBF3? 
Its a jRPG, where you go through the game and fight bosses, which become stronger and stronger. You start in a little town after a short cutscene. Afterwards you explore different locations, from a forest, up to a volcano and beyond. Every location has a boss, which you have to defeat, in order to continue your journey. Throughout the game are hidden chests. They often contain really nice items, like weapons and armors. At some places you can talk to NPCs and start a quest. They mostly consist of collect x amount of y. The rewards are really useful though. A lot of the quests will reward you with new skills, which are otherwise unattainable. Overall its a typical jRPG. Kill, grow stronger and kill the final boss.

[h1]Story[/h1]: 8/10

The story itself isn't really worth mentioning. Your team consists of 3 heroes which loose their powers at the beginning of the game. I wouldn't say that this game has a serious story. It is rather a funny story, which will yet keep you hooked and will entertain you throughout the game. You will read a lot of puns and jokes about Natalies boobs, but they arent really annoying or childish. Matt (the main hero) is your typical swordsmaster, Lance (my personal favourite) is your typical pervert and arms maniac and Natalie is your typical (hot) magician. You will learn to love each of them. Nothing too bad but also nothing too good.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]: 10/10

This is where the game REALLY shines. I really enjoyed every second of this game. The combat system of EBF3 is really entertaining and the boss battles are really tough. Beware though that I played this game on the highest difficulty. Even if you level up your heroes, the bosses will still provide a nice challenge. If you approach them the wrong way, you're screwed. Don't get me wrong though. Even though the bosses are challenging even after grinding for xp and materials, they are never unfair. You always know, that you could've done it better and might have saved up your limitbreak for a certain boss attack. As every RPG you level up by killing monsters, after you've reached a certain amount of XP. But other than leveling up, you also got equipment. Equipment in this game is REALLY essential, as it can mean victory of defeat in this game (thats why I said you'll never feel like you have been treated unfair, after loosing a battle). Each equipment part has its own stats. Some have resistances against fire attacks,ice attacks and so on, some apply certain buffs, some weapons deal elemental damage, some equipment parts will increase your resistance to certain debuffs like blind, silence and so on. As you can see, you can prepare yourself for every battle in EBF3. Beware though, there are some enemies who will change their elemental resistance throughout the battle. So you have to change your weapon for example from fire to ice and so on. Every weapon and equipment can be upgraded up to 5 times. Upgrading will cost materials (Materials can also used to complete certain quests). Each upgrade will increase their effectiveness by (most of the time) 10%. Level 4 to 5 will also ocasionally have an extra effect. For example Matts sword Heavens Gate will counter enemy attacks, when it's level 4 and will sometimes cast shine on level 5. 
Now to the skills. Every character can learn skills from a skill tree(Each has their own skill tree though). Usually you are free to pick every skill you want in the order you want. But you have to keep in mind that each skill has its own price. From the skill tree you can also learn your limitbreak. Limitbreaks are special attacks, which are avaivable after your characters have taken a certain amount of damage. These are especially strong attacks, which can be devastating.
There are some minigames, which can be REALLY frustrating, if you want 100% in EBF3 and especially if you want to unlock the secret dungeon,which you do once you got every achievement. But if you are patient enough, you will master these minigames too. They also reward you with items and gold.

[h1]Music[/h1]: 10/10

EBF3 has one of the best soundtrack I've heard. Every location has a song, that will blow your mind and suits the theme of it perfectly. You can easily listen to the soundtrack, while browsing the net or playing another game. I never got annoyed by any song in this game. Best of all? You get every song for free as mp3.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]: 10/10

I cant speak for the lower difficulties, since I've only played on the hardest setting. But hell this game is REALLY hard. Some might call me noob, but there were a lot of times, I got so frustrated, that I just needed a break. (Final boss reference ;)  ) As I have mentioned above though, you never want to quit the game forever because of the difficulty. You rather want to try again and again and again, grind a little and then try again, until you've beaten the boss. This game has one of the best rpg combat systems I've seen. Every boss has its own weakness and some certain things you have to watch out for. I really loved fighting every boss in this game. They all were a nice challenge and you had that feeling, that you have accomplished something. The best boss for me was the final boss. I remember back in the days, that I had quit this game, because I thought I'd never beat him. Several months later I tried again and again until I kicked his butt. Best moment of my life. Didn't regret anything. So if you're seeking a challenging game, try EBF3 on epic difficulty.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]: 10/10

It is, what it is. It's not 3d but yet the game and its locations look beautiful. Maps are designed with love, they dont look boring or repetetive. Everything is colorful, lively and well thought. I'm judging the graphics based on what it is. 

[h1]Overall[/h1]: 10/10 tl;dr

This game is a must have, if you love turn based rpgs. Awsome music, awesome combat system, awesome game and awesome dialogues ;). It's for free and has the soundtrack included. You will have a lot of fun with it. The actual playtime is based on your difficulty you play on. The epic difficulty can really take a lot of time to beat. I'd say from 10-30hours, depending on how good you are. 

So for your own sake, download the game already and play it. It's free!

25289800.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 returns from being a simple web game to being a simple downloadable game...

If you've played through the series and are looking for nostalgia, or are new to the series and like playing RPGs, then this game is for you! So what is this game?

25288643.review:
tl;dr Load it up, play for an hour. You'll know exactly what you're getting. It's free anyway.

I played this game originally on Kongregate, so ignore my brief play time. Epic Battle Fantasy 3 (EBF 3) is funny, quirky and well made and free. Yes. Quality content for free.
Edit: Finished the game. Reviews points remain.

The simple turn-based combat that harkens to a simpler RPG time coupled with hilarious dialogue and references makes for plenty of hours of fun. Plenty of collectibles and medals to satiate the inner-collector, perfectionist and achievement hunter. All of this can be done while listening to the great tunes of Phyrnna, who was responsible for most, if not all, of the music across all the games.

There were several quality of life improvements made that I greatly appreciate from Matt Roszak, the developer (aka Kupo Games). Rather than simply port EBF 3, it was improved upon, and if the minigames were as I remembered, an increase in easiness is VERY APPRECIATED. The link to all the features he added is below
http://kupogames.com/2016/08/31/ebf3-final-new-features-list/

The game graphics are as cute and endearing as ever, though its age did show in the full screen mode due to the resolution. I am however more than happy playing it in its windowed mode and give that and its few missing quality of life features a pass. For a flash game released 6 years ago, the game still holds up well in my eyes.

All in all, a definite recommend to RPG fans. Exactly what it says on the tin, and best of all, there's no need to wait years for its sequel. EBF 4 is already here (free on web only). Just scroll down.

Edit: There is a 2x speed function which I also greatly appreciated since I already played the game before and wanted to speed run it. It definitely helps speed up battles once you're done enjoying all the animations from the skills.

25286951.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 was a fantastic game before, and is a fantastic game now. This updated version is a great introduction into the EBF series, as it's free and simpler than EBF4. If you're unsure about whether or not you want to buy EBF4, play this game first - while EBF3 is much simpler, the core concepts are the same.

This game is full of colour and humour, and has a little something for everyone - oversized weapons, adorable enemies, fantastic boss fights, and anime boobs. While on the outside, the game seems cartoony and silly, the actual gameplay is refined and revolves around a lot of strategy, but has difficulty settings for everyone. On Easy mode you can get away with making mistakes, but on Epic mode you've [i]got[/i] to know what you're doing and how you're going to do it. Of course, real men play on Epic mode.

Now, my two favourite parts of the game: the boss fights, and the music. The boss fights in this game are actually quite challenging, but not to a frustrating point. They feel fair but tricky, and each boss has a strategy around it that keeps you on your toes. Each boss is different and brute force only gets you so far.

If you've read any reviews for any EBF-related game before, you'll have heard about the quality of the soundtrack - EBF3 is just one of several games with a fantastic soundtrack. The overworld music sets the atmosphere for each area so well, and the battle music is incredible - particularly the boss fights.

Now, unfortunately I have to compare it to EBF4. 3 is like a bite-size version of 4; both have epic music, great gameplay and interesting characters, but 4 is just so much more refined and polished, and introduces so many new mechanics. However, they're both great games. Chances are if you don't like 3, you probably won't like 4...and if you like 3, you'll [i]love[/i] 4. For a free game, EBF3 still has so much going for it.

Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a parody game and a sequel to the Epic Battle Fantasy series. It's possibly one of the best FREE indie RPG turn-based games out there since it won several indie awards from sites like Armour Games. (Even though it is a little out-datted from Matt's standards)

CONS:

25285815.review:
[h1]Before I even start: yes, this [i]is[/i] the same Epic Battle Fantasy 3 you probably played on some Flash hub or another back in 2010. Also, disclosure, I got a Steam key a few days early and have been playing, Let's Playing and writing reviews of these games for years so I guess you could argue I'm looking at this through the lens of a rather hyperbolic fanboy.[/h1]

[h1]Good[/h1]

So, what to say about Epic Battle Fantasy 3. On the one hand, it's a silly Flash game, it looks like a silly Flash game, it sounds like a silly Flash game, it's written like a silly Flash game and I suppose you could argue that it plays like a silly Flash game, but it's all put together very well. The art and graphics isn't [i]fantastic,[/i] but the style is very cohesive and the world map isn't so big that it starts to look repetitive. The sound effects and battle animations are cartoony and the characters sometimes exclaim "kek" (sic) or similar in battle, but it works because the entire [i]game[/i] has a cartoony aesthetic. The writing . . . well, you're probably not playing this kind of game if you want to experience Tolkien or Rowling, and, say it with me, the silly over-the-top save-the-world plot goes nicely with the silly over-the-top world of menacing giant squid and sentient giant monolith things.

The battles themselves are a turn-based system where you get to attack first every turn, there is no "speed" or "agility" stat, so I guess it doesn't toe the JRPG line [i]perfectly.[/i] Anyway, there isn't too much to say about the battles except that they can easily fall into the "Fire attack, heal and repeat" pattern and you can probably beat Easy and Normal modes that way, but if you want to strategize a little more there is a bit more you can do with playing with status effects and changing equips mid-battle.

If you want a full list of differences/fixes between this and the web version, [url=http://kupogames.com/2016/08/31/ebf3-final-new-features-list/]see here[/url].

[h1]Bad[/h1]

There are a couple spelling/English errors here and there throughout the game. It doesn't look terribly professional but they realistically don't have any affect on how the game plays so please don't bother complaining about it. I have no idea if they're going to be patched out by the time the game itself is released or anything like that.

There are a couple places where the music doesn't loop perfectly. But the music's still great so you won't see me complaining that some battle theme is half a measure off at the end or something.

[h1]I obviously have to compare this game to its successor, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/265610/]EBF4[/url], at some point, so here you go[/h1]

EBF4 boasts a longer story, fancier graphics, more to explore, Battle Mountain and a bunch of other things, but in a lot of strange ways I enjoy this game better. The battle system has fewer moves available and feels less overwhelming to start out with, and there are few enough that you could realistically try out all (most) of them throughout the course of a single playthrough. The game and game world themselves are shorter, and the level cap is 30 (I think the final enemies in the game top out at about level 32 or 33), so the end-game battles feel somewhat less long and dragged out. Lastly, while EBF4 overall probably has better music, [url=https://phyrnna.bandcamp.com/track/youll-never-guess-this][i]You'll Never Guess This[/i][/url] is easily my favorite song in all of Flash games.

Also, the font is in Comic Sans. I personally am in favor of adding DLC to EBF4 and Bullet Heaven 2 that changes all of the fonts in the game to Comic Sans.

[h1]tl;dr[/h1]

Good game, and if you don't believe me it's free (as in it doesn't even cost money) so there really is no downside to downloading it and trying it out for twenty minutes.

[s]If I see anyone reply with "I hate anime games" I will make sure to personally strangle you with a small planet.[/s]

So, where to start...
This game is a great RPG, with great gameplay, great story, great art, and great music.
It used to be online on websites such as Kongreate, but it's been ported to Steam so we won't lose our progress when we play again 5 years later or so.

There's little secrets everywhere and references too, and you're sure to have a great time playing this game. There's even minigames and fan art, and quests to do.
There's a variety of loudouts to choose from, and many skills to use. There's even limit breaks!
(There's also 7 save slots I think, so you could have multiple games at once, or just save over it.)

The only problems I see is that if you go fullscreen, the graphics aren't as good, and if you check out the fan art before unlocking it, you can briefly see the image before the "LOCKED" thing appears.

So, if you're a fan of Matt Kupo's work, or Phyrnna's music, or you played this and want the nostalgia to come to you, or you like humour, or RPG's, or the art style, you should probably check this out.
And if you don't?
Check it out anyways, it doesn't require much from your computer.

Other games by Matt Kupo (and sometimes Phyrnna) would be:
EBF
EBF2
EBF4 (On Steam)
